poem:
A was once an apple pie,
Pidy
Widy
Tidy
Pidy
Nice insidy, Apple Pie!

citation.title: Ye Baker, from Ye butcher, ye baker, ye candlestick maker
citation.source: The Public Domain Review
citation.blurb: Even though this looks as if it came straight out of a medieval book for children, this illustration is from a parody published in 1908.  It's worth reading.  My favorite is actually Ye Pirate.  It's suprisingly current for having been written over 100 years ago.

poem:
B was once a little bear,
Beary!
Wary!
Hairy!
Beary!
Taky cary, Little Bear!

citation.title: Polar Bear
citation.source: Library of Congress via the Public Domain Review
citation.blurb: My favorite part of this is the boat full of dudes trying to club away the 50 seals attacking their boat.

poem:
C was once a little cake,
Caky
Baky
Maky
Caky
Taky Caky, Little Cake!

citation.title: Still Life with Cake
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: Does cake count as still life?

poem:
D was once a little doll,
Dolly
Molly
Polly
Nolly
Nursy Dolly, Little Doll!

citation.title: A Vendor Selling Toys to a Child
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: I've always wanted to work on a José Posada piece, but I'm saving the next one for Dia De Los Muertos.  He does the best art for that.

poem:
E was once a little eel,
Eely,
Weely
Peely
Eely
Twirly, Tweedy Little Eel!

citation.title: Eels
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: All the makings of a tasty dish right here.

poem:
F was once a little fish,
Fishy
Wishy
Squishy
Fishy
In a Dishy, Little Fish!

citation.title: Poissons, Ecrevisses et Crabes
citation.source: The Biodiversity Heritage Library via The Public Domain Review
citation.blurb: The book this comes from is pretty great, too. These are illustrations of the fish in the West Indies, and around 9% of them are totally made up. The author calls himself an agent of the British crown in the introduction.  And did you notice the eel is labelled a Cambat Babi?  I love that.

poem:
G was once a little goose,
Goosy
Moosy
Boosy
Goosey
Waddly-woosy, Little Goose!

citation.title: The Goose Seller
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: I wish there were goose sellers walking down my street now.

poem:
H was once a little hen,
Henny
Chenny
Tenny
Henny
Eggsy-any, Little Hen?

citation.title: Cock and Hen
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection

poem:
I was once a bottle of ink,
Inky
Dinky
Thinky
Inky
Black Minky, Bottle of Ink!

citation.title: The Banker's Table
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection

poem:
J was once a jar of jam,
Jammy
Mammy
Clammy
Jammy
Sweety-Swammy, Jar of Jam!

citation.source: The Barnes Foundation
citation.title: The Ginger Jar (Pot de gingembre)

poem:
K was once a little kite,
Kity
Whity
Flighty
Kity
Out of sighty-Little Kite!

citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.title: Fukoroi: Flying Kites

poem:
L was once a little lark,
Larky!
Marky!
Harky!
Larky!
In the Parky, Little Lark!

citation.artist: William Home Lizars after John James Audubon
citation.title: Brown Lark
citation.source: The National Gallery of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: The 'after' artist means that it was done in the style of John James Audobon. I Googled it. You're welcome.

poem:
M was once a little mouse,
Mousey
Bousey
Sousy
Mousy
In the Housy Little Mouse!

citation.title: An Animal in the Moon
citation.source: The Public Domain Review
citation.blurb: I love all of the works of art in that article.  I would animate every single one if I could.

poem:
N was once a little needle,
Needly
Tweedly
Threedly
Needly
Wisky-wheedly Little Needle!

citation.title: Lady Threading Needle on Verandah
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: The title of this piece really sums it up, I think.

poem:
O was once a little owl,
Owly
Prowly
Howly
Owly
Browny fowly, Little Owl!

citation.title: Horned Owl from the Birds of America series (N4)
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: Allen & Ginter made this series of American birds as trading cards for their cigarettes.  There's way more than this, too!  I almost used the doll from another series for D, but it felt weird to have a little girl nursing a doll with a big "CIGARETTES" sign behind her.

poem:
P was once a little pump,
Pumpy
Slumpy
Flumpy
Pumpy
Dumpy, Thumpy, Little Pump!

citation.title: Hand Powered Fire Pump
citation.source: The National Gallery of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: This is the most beautiful fire truck that I have ever seen.  It also has the distinction of being the newest piece of art in this alphabet collection, which I would not have guessed if I had not read the description.

poem:
Q was once a little quail,
Quaily
Faily
Daily
Quaily
Stumpy-taily Little Quail!

citation.title: Quail, Sparrows, and Millet
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: The quails in this are adorable. Frankly, it was hard to pick a great quail image because there were so many!

poem:
R was once a little rose,
Rosy
Posy
Nosy
Rosy
Bows-y - grows-y Little Rose!

citation.title: Valentine - Mechanical floral scene - a man on a horse offers a woman a rose - symbol of love.
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: I love a good pop-up card.

poem:
S was once a little shrimp,
Shrimpy
Nimpy
Flimpy
Shrimpy
Jumpy-jimpy, Little Shrimp!

citation.title: The Aesop Prawn
citation.source: The Public Domain Review
citation.blurb: Okay, so apparently this is a 'Prawn' and not a 'Shrimp.' I apologize profusely because I was not aware that they were different things.

poem:
T was once a little thrush,
Thrushy!
Hushy!
Bushy!
Thrushy!
Flitty-Flushy
Little Thrush!

citation.title: An Orange-Headed Ground Thrush and a Death's-Head Moth on a Purple Ebony Orchid Branch
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: The moth is the moth from Silence of the Lambs.

poem:
U was once a little urn,
Urny
Burny
Turny
Urny
Bubbly-burny, Little Urn!

citation.title: Designs for Various Ornaments
citation.source: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: This is basically a page from a catalogue of very fancy house stuff.

poem:
V was once a little vine,
Viny
Winy
Twiny
Viny
Twisty-twiny, Little Vine!

citation.title: Callystegia soldanella, from De Materia Medica
citation.source: The Public Domain Review
citation.blurb: The title of this piece is the latin name of Morning Glory.  Even though it doesn't quite look like it in the picture, those of you with gardens will know it's a vine.  It's poisonous because it makes a cousin of LSD: LSA.  I guess that makes it medicinal?

poem:
W was once a whale,
Whaly
Scaly
Shaly
Whaly
Tumbly-taily, Mighty Whale!

citation.title: Toy Bank: "Jonah and the Whale"
citation.source: The National Gallery of Art Open Access Collection
citation.blurb: The first thing my daughter asked about this is how you put the money in. I'm guessing you put it in Jonah, and as he gets tossed overboard it lands in the whale?  This puts a piggy bank to shame.

poem:
X was once a great king Xerxes,
Xerxy
Perxy
Turxy
Xerxy
Linxy Lurxy, Great King Xerxes!

citation.title: Koning Xerxes I
citation.source: The Rijks Museum Collection

poem:
Y was once a little yew,
Yewdy
Fewdy
Crudy
Yewdy
Growdy, grewdy, Little Yew!

citation.title: Taxus Baccata. Common Yew.
citation.source: The Biodiversity Heritage Library
citation.blurb: This was one of the most difficult pieces to track down.  Rather than being a straight-up piece of art, this is a print from a book on British flowering plants.  The author's name is William Baxter, and I inferred the artist's name from the inscription at the bottom of the piece.  Hopefully I did them justice.

poem:
Z was once a piece of zinc,
Tinky
Winky
Blinky
Tinky
Tinkly Minky, Piece of Zinc!

citation.title: Usine de la Vieille Montagne
citation.source: The Internet Archive
citation.blurb: Finding classic art with a picture of zinc was really difficult, so this piece needs some explanation.  The Vieille Montagne was a zinc mine in Belgium.  This is an illustration from a French paper that shows the inside of the factory, so what you see is probably the rolled zinc that the mine became world-famous for producing.
